info.name: Description
info.content: MERIT DEM: Multi-Error-Removed Improved-Terrain DEM. The MERIT DEM was developed by removing multiple error components (absolute bias, stripe noise, speckle noise, and tree height bias) from the existing spaceborne DEMs (SRTM3 v2.1 and AW3D-30m v1). It represents the terrain elevations at a 3sec resolution (~90m at the equator)Last Update: 15 Oct, 2018

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content:
The Mekong River Commission makes no warranties about the data deliniated and disclaims all responsibility and reliability for all expences, losses, damages and costs which maybe incurred as a result of the data being inaccurate or incomplete in any way and for any reason.

info.name: Access and acknowledgements
info.content:
Online data (original data) could be access from

http://hydro.iis.u-tokyo.ac.jp/~yamadai/MERIT_DEM/index.html

The dataset could also found from Google Earth Engine :

https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/datasets/catalog/MERIT_DEM_v1_0_3

Citation:

Yamazaki D., D. Ikeshima, R. Tawatari, T. Yamaguchi, F. O'Loughlin, J.C. Neal, C.C. Sampson, S. Kanae & P.D. Bates, A high accuracy map of global terrain elevations, Geophysical Research Letters, vol.44, pp.5844-5853, 2017 doi: 10.1002/2017GL072874

members.id: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Core River Monitoring Network

members.id: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Core River Monitoring Network/Ecological Health Monitoring 2021
shareKeys: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Core River Monitoring Network/Ecological Health Monitoring 2021
members.name: Ecological Health 2021

info.name: Description
info.content:
The routine Ecological Health Monitoring (EHM) data and map have been implemented in a biennial basis (starting from 2011, 2013, 2015, 2017, 2019, and 2021) and three indicator metrics of the health of the Mekong aquatic ecosystem have been calculated for each of the four groups of the organisms: benthic diatoms, zooplankton, littoral macroinvertebrates, and benthic macroinvertebrates. The metrics are average abundance, average richness and ATSPT of each of the four groups. A healthy ecosystem is indicated by high abundance, high average richness, and low ATSPT. Each metric has been calculated for individual samples of each group of organisms. The Ecological Health Monitoring (EHM) program was developed and undertaken on a biennial basis. There are 41 monitoring locations across the LMB with eight each in Lao PDR, Thailand and Viet Nam, and 17 in Cambodia.

In 2021, the site assessment results showed that thirty-six (36) stations (or 87.80%) have been evaluated as “Good” (Class B) condition, three (03) stations in Cambodia (or 7.32%) have been evaluated as “Excellent” (Class A) condition, and one (01) station each in Lao PDR and Thailand (or 4.88%) has been evaluated as “Moderate” (Class C) condition, respectively.

The data was recently updated on May, 2021.

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content:
The Mekong River Commission makes no warranties about the data deliniated and disclaims all responsibility and reliability for all expences, losses, damages and costs which maybe incurred as a result of the data being inaccurate or incomplete in any way and for any reason.

info.content:

MRC (2010) Biomonitoring Methods for the Lower Mekong Basin. Mekong River Commission, Vientiane. 65 pp.

For more information : https://portal.mrcmekong.org/ehm

info.name: Data source
info.content: Original data sources are from “Biomonitoring Methods for the Lower Mekong Basin” which was published in April 2010

members.id: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Core River Monitoring Network/Water Quality Index
shareKeys: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Core River Monitoring Network/Water Quality Index
members.name: Water Quality 2021

info.name: Description
info.content:
Based on a review of the scientific literature and a statistical analysis of the MRC data, a Water Quality Index has been designed based on a set of key water quality parameters. The Water Quality Index shows the pressure exerted by human activities on the water quality of the Mekong River.

The dataset including 4 indexes of Human Health Index, Aquatic Life Index, Agriculture use for general irrigation index, and general use for Paddy irrigation index.

The Water Quality Index is calculated each year. Most updated data for Water Quality Index is updated year 2021.

members.id: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Core River Monitoring Network/Fishery Station
shareKeys: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Core River Monitoring Network/Fishery Station
members.name: Fishery Station

info.name: Description
info.content:
The MRC fisheries monitoring consists of three types: Dai fisheries Monitoring on the Tonle Sap River, Fish Larvae Drift Monitoring (FLDM) and Fish Abundance and Diversity Monitoring (FADM). The monitoring measures yield indicators contributing to the interpretation of the status and trends of basin-wide capture fisheries and provides effective means to assess the effects of development activities on water resources in the basin.

Significant fisheries monitoring stations have been addressed and included in the Core River Monitoring Network (CRMN) together with the other four environmental disciplines: hydrology, sediments, water quality, and ecological health.

The former fisheries monitoring network was made of 38 FADM stations and 8 FLDM stations, plus Dai fisheries and 4 JEM stations. The redesigned CRMN is made of 38 FADM stations (including Dai fisheries), and 10 FLDM stations, i.e. 48 stations.

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content:

info.name: Access and acknowledgements
info.content:
The data was developed by using the information from MRC riparian staff in its routine fisheries monitoring programs as follows:

- Cambodia: Fisheries Administration (FiA), Tonle Sap Authority (TSA)

- Lao PDR: Living Aquatic Resources Research Center (LARReC), National Agriculture Forestry Institute (NAFRI), Department of Livestock and Fisheries (DLF)

- Thailand: Department of Fisheries (DOF), Inland Fisheries Research and Development Division

- Viet Nam: Research Institute for Aquaculture No2 (RIA2)

shareKeys: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Core River Monitoring Network/DSMP Station
members.name: Discharge & Sediment Monitoring Station

info.name: Description
info.content:
This data represents the location of MRC Discharge and Sediment Monitoring (DSM) Sites. It consists of existing and planned sites as a part of MRC Core River Monitoring Network (CRMN).

The data collected for the sites are discharge, suspended sediment concentration, sediment bedload and bed materials, bedload grains-size, river cross-sections, which those data are used for water-discharge rating curve development, calculated sediment load/flux and so on.

info.name: Description
info.content:
This data represents the location of hydrometeorological monitoring stations under the MRC monitoring system. It consists of existing stations which are identified either as a station included or excluded from a part of MRC Core River Monitoring Network (CRMN). Also, consists of new stations to be added for the CRMN.

The stations are mostly with automatic data transmission which monitor mainly water level and rainfall in every 15mins.

shareKeys: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Deep Pools & Rapids/deeppools
members.name: Deep Pools

info.name: Description
info.content: The data represent the pools identified from a statistical analysis of the riverbed long profile (a plot of river depth along the line of deepest flow versus distance downstream) of the lower Mekong River. Pools were identified by fitting a trend to the long profile and then selecting all depressions beneath the trend line

members.id: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Deep Pools & Rapids/Deep Pools LEK
shareKeys: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Deep Pools & Rapids/Deep Pools LEK
members.name: Deep Pools LEK

info.name: Description
info.content: The data is the location of the pools identified from local ecological knowledge (LEK) obtained during several independent surveys conducted between 1995 and 2010. These surveys identified pools based on interviews with fisher groups in ecologically significant areas and productive fishing grounds, often in combination with field surveys of river bathymetry (depth) and interpretation of existing bathymetric maps. Some pools identified in these surveys did not have geographic coordinates and so have not been included in this map. Only some tributaries have been surveyed.

members.id: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension//Land Use Land Cover/LC2010
shareKeys: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension//Land Use Land Cover/LC2010
members.name: Land Cover 2010

info.name: Description
info.content:
The Project to Update the Land Cover Map of the Lower Mekong Basin for 2010 was designed to produce three data sets based on 19 types of single-class land cover based on the FAO Land Cover Classification System.

To establish a baseline for producing an updated and qualified land cover data set and catalogue for the basin, the National Mekong Committees and line agencies collected field data on land cover between October 2011 and February 2012. The main objectives were to collect, compile and provide accurate and reliable information to help interpret satellite imagery, conduct achievable accuracy assessments, and establish a land cover information catalogue for the LMB.

The project acquired Landsat 5 Thematic Mapper satellite images for pre-processing. There were 40 images covering the Lower Mekong Basin (LMB) and 80 images for both the dry and wet periods, mostly taken in 2009 and 2010.

info.name: Description
info.content: Enhancing MRC's Land Use/Land Cover 2020 Mapping Products for Lower Mekong Basin (LMB). MRCS aims to implement and generate new datasets of LULC map 2020 including their information catalogue on annual datasets for disseminating through MRC-IS. This database was generate by using remote sensing data for year 2020 (Landsat8, Sentinel1, Sentinel2, and Plannet) along with cloud computing and machine learning technique.

info.name: Access and acknowledgements
info.content:
Cambodia National Mekong Committee (CNMC), Phnom Penh Geoinformatics Education Center (PGEC) from Cambodia

Laos National Mekong Committee (LNMC), Forest Inventory and Planning Division (FIPD) from Lao PDR

Thailand National Mekong Committee (TNMC), Land Development Department (LDD) from Thailand

Vietnam National Mekong Committee (VNMC), Sub-National Institute of Agricultural Planning and Projection (Sub-NIAPP) from Vietnam

info.name: Data source
info.content: Enhancing MRC's Land Use/Land Cover 2020 Mapping Products for Lower Mekong Basin (LMB), MRC 2021

info.name: Description
info.content:
Fish habitat classification distinguishing 7 habitat types: the 4 major habitats with aquaculture in the major flood zone, rainfed zone, and brackish-estuarine area classified separately. The project is done by July 2022

The JRC Yearly Water Classification History data (with a native resolution of 30m) were accessed through the Google Earth Engine to determine maximum annual flood extents for the period 2010-2019. Forest canopy prohibits the JRC dataset to appropriately classify inundated area, therefore the flooded forest extent from the TD LU/LC 2020 map was added to the major flood zone class. Reservoirs and other water bodies data were extracted from the Second Basin Development Plan. Built-up areas and all other lands based on the Urban class in the MRC Technical Support Division (TD) Land Use / Land Cover (LU/LC) product for 2020, which are not part of the major flood zone, nor of any of the other habitat types (i.e., aquacultures), were removed.

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content:
The Mekong River Commission makes no warranties about the data deliniated and disclaims all responsibility and reliability for all expences, losses, damages and costs which maybe incurred as a result of the data being inaccurate or incomplete in any way and for any reason.

info.name: Access and acknowledgements
info.content:

members.id: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Fish Migration Pattern
shareKeys: Mekong Basin Atlas/Environmental Dimension/Fish Migration Pattern
members.name: Fish Migration Pattern

info.name: Description
info.content: Fisheries ecologists have distinguished three main fish migration systems in the LMB as illustrated in the map: the Lower Mekong (altitude 0-150 m above sea level), the Middle Mekong (altitude 150-200 masl) and the Upper Mekong (altitude 200-500 masl).

info.content:
The Mekong River Commission makes no warranties about the data deliniated and disclaims all responsibility and reliability for all expences, losses, damages and costs which maybe incurred as a result of the data being inaccurate or incomplete in any way and for any reason.

The data contained herein do not imply the expression of any opinion whatsoever on the part of the Mekong River Commission concerning the legal status of any country, territory, city or area or of its authorities, or concerning the delineation of its frontiers or boundaries.

info.name: Description
info.content:
The LMB Wetland 2020 has been developed based on 'Wetlands of LMB, Cambodia, Lao PDR, Thailand, and Viet Nam' created on 15 December 2015 by Dr. Charlotte MacAlister, with its original author of Ms. Penroong Bamrungrach.

This updated data layer has been improved by incorporating the updated satellite imagery data, acquired from Landsat 8 or Sentinel-2 imageries and Sentinel-1 imageries, and then followed by reclassifying based on the FAO-LCCS software application. Lastly, to increase more accuracy, the 2020 Land Use/ Land Cover map from TD had been incorporated for further validation.

info.name: Disclaimer

info.name: Access and acknowledgements
info.content: The data was developed by using the information from Dr. Charlotte MacAlister, with its original author of Ms. Penroong Bamrungrach.

info.name: Data source
info.content:
Original data sources:

Cambodia: old MRC data, suspected that this dataset derived from Cambodian land use map, 1992/1993 created under MRC/UNEP land use mapping project from the previous MRCS TD.

Lao PDR: Topographic map at scale 1:250,000, Landsat and Spot which acquired between 1987-1992, and field survey from the MRC Wetland Mapping Project: Wetland Mapping in Laos, 1992/1993.

Thailand: Soil map and land use map at scale 1:50,000 and field survey, 2003 from Land Development Department, Ministry of Agriculture (Contact: Mr. Somsak Pititeerapap, Agronomist at Research and Development to Combat Desertification and Early Warning Institute, Land Development Department, Thailand (Email: irw_6@ldd.go.th )

Viet Nam: wetland map 2002 from Sub Institute of Water Resource Planning (SIWRP)

info.name: Description
info.content:
Biological Resource Assessment (BioRA) zone was developed for the council study on Sustainable Management and Development of the Mekong River Basin, including Impacts of Mainstream Hydropower Projects. The final report was done on December 2017. The layer contains 8 different zone of the BioRA which are :

Zone 1: Mekong River from the border with China to Pak Beng (confluence with Nam Beng)

Zone 2: Mekong River from downstream of the Nam Beng to upstream of Vientiane

Zone 3: Mekong River from Vientiane to Nam Kam town (near confluences with Xe Bang Fei and Nam Kam)

Zone 4: Mekong River from Nam Kam to Stung Treng (Se San / Se Kong confluences)

Zone 5: Mekong River from Stung Treng to Kampong Cham

Zone 6: Tonle Sap River at Prek Kdam, plus the Cambodian Floodplains excluding Zone 5 and 7

Zone 7: Tonle Sap Great LakeZone 8: The Vietnamese Delta from the Cambodian/Viet Nam border to the sea

Zone 8: The Vietnamese Delta from the Cambodian/Viet Nam border to the sea

info.name: Description
info.content:
In hydropower sector, the MRC is tasked to help ensure that increasing demand for electric energy in the Member Countries is met without causing detrimental effects on the environment or local communities an aim which requires a hydropower strategy that is based on best practices.

There are 4 information in this dataset which are : Status, Mean Annual Energy, Installed capacity, and Live Storage

The data is updated to year 2021

members.id: Mekong Basin Atlas/Climate Change Dimension/Drought/Drought risk
shareKeys: Mekong Basin Atlas/Climate Change Dimension/Drought/Drought risk
members.name: Drought Risk

info.name: Description
info.content:
Drought risk of the LMB is generated through multidimensional factors including drought hazard, exposure, and vulnerability. All the three main indicators - meteorological, hydrological, and agricultural indicators - are used to compute drought hazard with 43 years of historical records. Human population, landcover, and baseline water stress data for 2020 are used to quantify exposure levels within the LMB area. While groundwater potential and areas with irrigation are used to evaluate drought vulnerabilities in the region.

Four categories of drought risk are used to measure the risk levels. They are (1) no or mild, (2) mild-moderate, (3) moderate-severe, and (4) severe-extreme.

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content:

info.name: Description
info.content:
SPI was generated using observed rainfall satellite called Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data (CHIRPS) with over 40 years historical record. The availability of the SPI maps is from 1981 to 2022. The data layer here is represent the most recent year (2022)

Resolution: the original resolution of the data is 5km.

For more information about the product : http://droughtforecast.mrcmekong.org/maps

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content:

info.name: Data source
info.content:
Online data (original data) could be access from:

https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirps

The dataset could also found from Google Earth Engine:

https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/datasets/catalog/UCSB-CHG_CHIRPS_DAILY#:~:text=Climate%20Hazards%20Group%20InfraRed%20Precipitation%20with%20Station%20data%20(CHIRPS)%20is,analysis%20and%20seasonal%20drought%20monitoring.

info.name: Description
info.content:
SRI was generated using runoff dataset as the outputs from the Variable Infiltration Capability (VIC). VIC was operated under the Regional Hydrological Extreme Assessment System (RHEAS) with over 40 years historical record. The availability of the SRI maps is from 1981 to 2022.The data layer here is represent the most recent year (2022)

Resolution: the original resolution of the data is 5km.

For more information about the product : http://droughtforecast.mrcmekong.org/maps

VIC was operated under the Regional Hydrological Extreme Assessment System (RHEAS) with over 40 years historical record. The availability of the SMA maps is from 1981 to 2022.The data layer here is represent the most recent year (2022)

members.id: Mekong Basin Atlas/Climate Change Dimension/Drought/Drought Severity SPI
shareKeys: Mekong Basin Atlas/Climate Change Dimension/Drought/Drought Severity SPI
members.name: Drought Severity (SPI 2000-2022)

info.name: Description
info.content:
SPI-based drought severity from 2000 to 2022 was generated through annual SPIs during 2000-2022.

Resolution: the original resolution of the data is 5 km.

Drought classification for SPI-Drought Severity:

Extreme drought: SPI value less than -0.3

Severe drought: -0.3 to -0.2

Moderate drought: -0.2 to -0.05

No drought: SPI value more than -0.05

For more information about the product : http://droughtforecast.mrcmekong.org/maps

info.name: Description
info.content:
SPI-based drought frequency data from 2000 to 2009 were generated based on the number of drought occurrences (SPI value =<-1) through annual SPIs.

Resolution: the original resolution of the data is 5 km.

Drought classification for SPI-Drought Frequency:

Drought : SPI = <-1

Maximum number of drought occurrence : 7 times

info.name: Description
info.content: Annual rainfall (in mm) is extracted from Soil Water Assessment Tool (SWAT) as a hydrological model using 228 observed rainfall stations across Lower Mekong Basin (LMB). This data is an annual average rainfall from 1985 to 2020 in 680 SWAT subbasins, which does not cover the floodplain areas located at the downstream part of LMB.

info.name: Description
info.content: Annual runoff or water yield (in mm) is extracted from Soil Water Assessment Tool (SWAT) as a hydrological model using 228 rainfall stations and 39 climatic stations across Lower Mekong Basin (LMB) in associated with other data required by the model. This data is an annual average runoff from 1985 to 2020 in 680 SWAT subbasins, which does not cover the floodplain areas located at the downstream part of LMB.

members.name: Flood occurance during 2016-2021

info.name: Description
info.content: Flood extent during 2016-2021, Sentinel1-SAR imagery was use for generated annual flood layer for all 6 years then combine to be flood frequency of the 2016-2021. The layer illustrates the flood extent as well as the frequency ranging from 1-6 times of the flood occurring.

info.name: Access and acknowledgements
info.content: Regional Flood and Drought Management Centre (RFDMC), MRCS

info.name: Data source
info.content: Report on Flood extent and flood assessment in the Lower Mekong Basin, Regional Flood and Drought Management Centre (RFDMC), MRCS

members.id: Mekong Basin Atlas/Climate Change Dimension/People affected to flood
shareKeys: Mekong Basin Atlas/Climate Change Dimension/People affected to flood
members.name: Estimated people affected to flood

info.name: Description
info.content: The number of people affected was estimated using grieded population dataset from Joint Research Centre (JRC), European Commission. The analysis using the flood extent from the period of year 2016-2022
